description: An almost jelly-like substance filling a similarly liquid-based petri dish, it's difficult to even hold. You can stretch it thin and hold it up to the light to make out detailed yet bizarre musings holographically imprinted in the goings-on of this microcosm.
A small glass bottle filled with a storm that grows continuously, meditating on it teaches you about the indomitable nature of the human spirit.
A ticket with a list of names you don't recognize. Checking off one name just makes another appear in it's place.
A sheet of light that seems to dance, no matter the lighting. You can hear a faint sound far away while you hold it, enticing and beautiful.

A small piece of cardboard that looks like it was cut from a magazine from 100 years ago. A cartoonish wizard on the front grins devilishly and points to a box with the words 'YOURS, FREE, NO HOOK, NO LINE, NO SINKER.' You find that when you look away, you know how to cast a new spell. You're not sure what it cost you.
A small music box that when opened speaks in a language you don't understand. The voice eventually resonates with you, and you feel overwhelmed with great empathy.

An idol made of jade and gold depicting a wizard. Tiny gold coins flow from their outstretched hands constantly, each one stamped with a lesson. The coins fade to nothing before they can reach the ground, making learning anything nearly impossible.
A clockwork dragon small enough to fit in your average pocket, lazily sleeping the day away. When awoken, he bargains for some shut eye by offering to teach you how to be more like yourself.
A very long, very boring book that says every word twice.
This teapot lets off the constant miasma of petroleum, heated or no.

A tiny tailor that you can only sixth-sense. While you're paying attention you can notice them weaving something around you, but you can't interact with them in any physical way. On a whim, you name the clothing of your desire and the ethereal tailor might be able to weave it up for you. You somehow know that wigs and armor don't fall under free use, and you'll have to visit the shop for those.
A scroll much like a blueprint, showing the intricacies of golems and their craft.
A scroll that you can only see out of the corner of your eye. The ink also seems to be perpetually running off the page, making it a nightmare to read.
An envelope that describes a spell, except every once in a while it forcefully pulls you an inch closer to it.

A single page torn from a book, nearly unrecognizable through the miasma of life oozing off of it. Spores and blood and mold and all other thinkable kinds of life are teeming here, ready to teach if one knows how to learn.
A letter made of kevlar. Seems excessive, but it got the job done.
An old photograph that reminds you of home. In fact, the more you look at it, that's literally your happy place...
This poorly stapled booklet is made of multiple layers of penta-colored construction paper that flip and flutter about as you hold them. It's surprisingly difficult to comprehend.

A ligher made in the shape of a .50 caliber bullet. Flicking it produces a flash of letters, which combined with more flicks describe the casting of a devastating spell. It seems the lighter was created to hide such a potentially powerful spell.
Staring into this solemn, unblinking eyeball slowly teaches you something you're not quite sure you're comfortable with. You're certainly not comfortable with the teacher.
This scroll refuses to stop spinning. Very, very difficult to read!
Written in the format of a love poem, including a 'sincerely yours', this brief treatise discusses the innate connection between beings and how best to achieve that supreme oneness.
A jar of murky water that smells distinctly of the ocean, you hope. As you sniff, you discover you can read it by smell alone. Doesn't make it smell any better.
A perfectly formed and delightfully realistic ice cream cone made of plastic. Licking the cold scoop on top has no taste, but you find you know just a little bit more about... something. Dig in!
An extremly soft handkerchief embroidered with a saga of quiet disappearance. Reading it strikes your soul, and teaches you to walk carefully in this life.

What appears at first to be a human being's head is actually a single piece of paper with a face stretched over it. When prompted the lips start moving and in a remarkably political way it begins describing ways to change hearts and minds.
A piece of paper that reflects like a mirror, showing you every imperfection and how to fix it.
A briefcase filled with papers from someone else's life, yet somehow you know it belongs to you. Searching is leading you somewhere...
A little black sedan on a keychain that's been flattened like a credit card. On the back are some extremely small instructions on how to use the card. Just hope there's still money on it.
A little black sedan on a keychain that's been flattened like a credit card. On the back are some extremely small instructions on how to use the card. Whatever you need to use it again, it's out.
A stand-alone fingerprint that won't stop wagging it's disapproval. The more you look at the print, the more you agree with it.
Hey, this is the exact one you were looking for!
A disposable phone that has a person on the other end trying to sell you drugs.
A hummingbird that pesters you for days on end, but cannot be interacted with by most physical means. Watching it's wings flap gives you some insight into weightlessness and non-locality.

A little solid gold eagle statuette like you might see on a school principal's desk. Looking closely, you can discern that the bird is made of solid gold but is actually a hunched hawk or some other sprawled, predatory mammal. This revelation leads you to another, which is that a solid gold gun would be really badass.
A single card from a deck with vague, silly instructions on how to release some magic inside the cards. Mostly it just urges you to do it.
A tag much like what you'd find on a new hat that briefly describes how to pull a rabbit presumably out of said hat.
A sheet of music that, once deciphered, describes how to release fire into the world at some cost to your heart and soul.
A receipt for a very expensive hat. The hat's title is so long and extensive that you can reverse-engineer it's entire formation.
Someone's dry reporting of the magic being used in pursuit of obtaining power from demons.
A marked envelope from one of many corporate spell-casting services, containing both abrupt and frustrating instructions on how to cast a spell.
An envelope covered in ice that's very difficult to get open. When it is opened, you find both abrupt and frustrating instructions on how to cast a spell.
A bowl of soup that brings back only your warmest memories, but still leaves you hungry.
A marked scroll from one of many corporate spell-casting services, containing both abrupt and frustrating instructions on how to cast a spell.
A math-filled binder that was due the day before the cataclysm.
A stop sign that's subtely flashing, only so much as to draw in your attention. It's hypnotizing, really.
A marked envelope from one of many corporate spell-casting services, containing both abrupt and frustrating instructions on how to cast a spell.
A newspaper filled with horrible stories. You can't believe this is costing you money.
An essay on how to do a lot of really disgusting shit. You can't be entirely sure where it came from, but it's definitely official.
A little safe about the size of your hand. You find it nearly impossible to open, as everytime you try it suddenly jumps across the room. Trying teaches you a thing or two about perfect form.
A set of indictment papers, addressed to you. They're written as if you should know all this already, so it's gonna be a real pain to get through.
A mug stamped with one of many interchangeable company logos, which fills with ethereal coffee. Drinking it has no taste, but you do feel like you're learning something.
A pre-rolled joint that, as you smoke it, becomes more and more obviously laced with something. By the time you've started you're ready to stop, but you're learning too much.
A potted venus fly trap, awaiting it's prey. The longer you have it, the more it grows on you. It's just so cute, you feel a need to take it with you everywhere you go.

A poster that's trying to advertise so many block buster events at once that it's impossible to discern even one. Carefuly peeling back stickers and stapled-on fliers, you start to reveal the original poster.
An everfrosted and ancient stone tablet detailing the tale of the warrior known only as the White Wolf. Strangely enough, despite it's age the tale it tells is definitively modern.
A small plastic container with a pop-top and a cartoonish wizard on the front. Inside is a disgusting black ooze that, when played with, transmits something to you.
A pink dollhouse, complete with dolls. At first it appears mundane, but soon you notice the dolls acting out a play of sorts. They attempt to show you how to make your bed.
A decanter like for alcoholic drinks, except when you pour the only thing that comes out is a neigh. You might get something out of it, eventually.

A spur like you'd find on a boot made of alabaster (or perhaps ivory). Spinning it around for a while your finger is pricked and you find yourself suddenly motivated, until it fades and you find yourself craving more.
A crown of solid gold, encrusted with gemstones that melt from it at all times. They burn the face of the wearer slightly, but with the pain comes knowledge of something... intimate.

A piece of paper that's been covered in layer after layer of graphite, making it almost 3-dimensional. The layers stack upon one another so that one just may be able to make out a face in the darkness.
A short length of rope with knots every foot or so. Somehow you find that as you untangle the individual threads, you become aware of a sensation of impermanence.
A glass eyeball slightly larger than your palm. No matter how you look at it, the eye looks back, and the longer you stare the more you learn.
An old-school record that let's out the faint sound of an unprovoked skip every few minutes. Listening closely, you start to hear voices in that skipping.
A wilting clover with four leaves. Watching the life fade from it fills you with a sense of purpose, but it is also very sad.
A clock that's stuck at 9:03. You're not sure if it's AM or PM, but as you look you feel yourself losing focus; waiting for a tick that will never come.

A little jar filled with oils that make you feel somehow both more and less like yourself. Smelling them long enough gives you a euphoric feeling of oneness, but once you stop you feel like an alien in your own body.
An arm-length purple and gold crystal that beautifully refracts the light. Staring at it endows you with a sense of great stillness.
A long, bent nail made of iron that holds closed a coffin of secrets. When it touches your skin it burns ancient knowledge of attraction into you.
A small switch on a palm-sized dias. Reaching out towards it causes the switch to flip rapidly, and in disapproval. When (and if) you get it to flip, you might learn something.

A little machine similar to an old camera with a long cylinder on the front above a slot. Reaching out to touch the cylinder results in an electrostatic shock, after which the machine prints a readout of data. Enough data, and you might have something.

A well made brochure with information on nearly every place in the world, absolutely none of it useful. At the end is an advertisement for 'Conjure Gate,' which you painstakingly surmise the casting from.

A tiny little paperback notebook emblazoned with the silhouette of a wizard grinning cheekily and pointing down. If the pages of the book are flipped rapidly, drawings of the wizard display the proper form for drawing the magic from within the cards. Careful, it looks chaotic.
